topic.title: Recovering Vertica after File System Issues

abstract.shortdesc: In , the monitoring service uses Vertica as its database. If it is configured incorrectly, or if a higher than expected load is experienced, and the file system fills up then Vertica may fall over and need to be recreated. This page shows scenarios and how to resolve them.

body.p: In , the monitoring service uses Vertica as its database. If it is configured incorrectly, or if a higher than expected load is experienced, and the file system fills up then Vertica may fall over and need to be recreated. In these cases you will need to recreate the Vertica database as described below.

Prior to getting to that point you may see the Disk Usage alarm trigger, which is a sign that the file system is filling up. If you can resolve this issue quickly using the steps below then you can prevent the Vertica database failure.
This page describes this scenario and how to resolve it.

section.title: Changing the Vertica retention period
section.p: If the Disk Usage alarm has triggered against the mount_point: /var/vertica and the Vertica database and API is still up, you can change the retention period using the steps below while you resolve the issue:

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Edit the configuration file noted below to edit the retention period.
The configuration file to edit is:~/helion/my_cloud/config/monasca/configuration.yml
Change the vertica_retention_period value to the number of days you want to hold Monasca data in Vertica. If your Vertica file system just filled up, or is close to doing so, make sure you are lowering it to a value less than the amount of days it took to fill in the first place.The section looks like this, bolded for emphasis: # Retention variables kafka_low_disk_retention: 1800000 # 30 minutes in milliseconds kafka_log_retention_hours: "{{ monasca_tunings.kafka_log_retention_hours }}" vertica_retention_period: 45 # 45 day default retention
Commit your configuration to the local git repo, as follows: git commit -a -m "changing Vertica retention period"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Update your deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Run this playbook which will reconfigure the cronjob on the controller nodes: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-deploy.yml --tags monasca-schema-vertica

From your first controller node (which may be your lifecycle manager), manually run the newly created Vertica cleanup cronjob: sudo /etc/cron.daily/vertica-cleanup
After this, it will automatically run once every 24 hours.

section.title: Recreating the Vertica database
section.note: These steps will delete all of your existing data. It should be used as last resort.
section.p: If your Vertica database has failed due to file system issues, you will need to recreate it and these steps will show you how.

ol.li: On each of your controller nodes that is running the vertica service, run this command which will remove the logrotate directory for Vertica: sudo rm -rf /opt/vertica/config/logrotate
Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Remove the Vertica database: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-vertica-dbclean.yml -e "force='yes'"
Reinstall the Vertica database: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-deploy.yml --tags vertica,monasca-schema-vertica

Restart the API and Persister by running these two playbooks: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-stop.yml --tags monasca-api,persister ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-start.yml --tags monasca-api,persister

Check the status of Vertica:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-status.yml --tags verticaVertica is not started under systemd. To check the process status from a host command line use sudo /etc/init.d/verticad status. The monasca-status.yml playbook reports whether Vertica thinks a node is down or not. The verticad process could be running when the node is down, so monasca-status is a more accurate way to tell if a Vertica host is up.
At this point your Vertica database should be recreated. You may want to consider lowering the retention period if this was the source of the problem. Details can be found here: .
